citeinfo.origin: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research (OAR), Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory (PMEL)
citeinfo.title: Deep-ocean Assessment and Reporting of Tsunamis (DART) (PMEL Tsunami)

abstract.p: Six DART systems currently provide coverage: three stations near the seismically active Alaska-Aleutian Seismic Zone (AASZ), which has a long history of tsunamigenic earthquakes; two stations off the Washington-Oregon coast near the Cascadia Subduction Zone (CSZ); and a sixth station in the eastern equatorial region to measure tsunamis which may be generated in the Peru-Chile Seismic Zone and propagate into the north Pacific. DART systems utilize a bottom pressure recorder (BPR) to measure low period sea level phenomena such as the tides and tsunamis, an acoustic link to transmit the BPR data to a surface buoy, and satellite telemetry to relay the data to shore.
DART was developed by NOAA'S NOAA's Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory (PMEL) and is operated by NOAA's National Data Buoy Center (NDBC).
Real-time data are available on the National Data Buoy Center website http://www.ndbc.noaa.gov/dart.shtml

descript.purpose: To provide deep-ocean tsunami measurements in real-time during an actual event.

idinfo.useconst: Contact the National Data Buoy Center.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system. NOAA makes no warranty, expressed or implied, nor does the fact of distribution constitute such a warranty.
